Situation1: They join in when the family talks about possible weekend plans.
Expectation2: Follow traffic laws and drive defensively
Situation2: A school zone with children near the curb appears just as a construction detour narrows the lanes
Story:
I sat at the dinner table, nodding along as my younger sister excitedly listed all the things she wanted to do this weekend—picnic at the park, movie night, maybe even a board game marathon. Mom looked at me, her eyes hopeful, and I knew she wanted me to promise I’d be there, really be present, not just in the room but part of the family. I said I’d try, and I meant it.

The next morning, I was behind the wheel of my taxi, weaving through the city. My mind replayed my sister’s smile, the way she’d tugged at my sleeve, asking if I’d play Monopoly with her. Suddenly, a construction detour forced me into a single narrow lane. Up ahead, a school zone sign flashed, and kids clustered near the curb, some darting dangerously close to the street. The car behind me honked impatiently, but I knew I had to slow down, follow the rules, keep everyone safe—even if it meant running late and risking missing out on family plans. My hands tightened on the wheel as I wrestled with the pressure to be a good sibling and a responsible driver, feeling pulled in two directions at once.
